Canadian extreme coastal water levels.source: Canadian Extreme Water Level Adaptation Tool
Canadian extreme coastal water levels.description: provides estimates future extreme water levels for a range of Canadian coastal locations.

Relative sea level change.description: describes relative change in sea level around Canada's coasts.

marine coastal flooding.direction_statement: Relative sea level is expected to rise along many Canadian coastlines.  However, particularly in the North, sea level may actually fall because of ongoing natural land uplift.
marine coastal flooding.direction_confidence: There is reasonably high confidence in the direction of projected sea level changes around Canada's coastlines.
marine coastal flooding.magnitude_confidence: There is less confidence in the exact magnitude of changes to sea level at specific locations.
marine coastal flooding.impact_statement: Via coastal flood events, sea level rise can indundate building interiors, erode foundations and surrounding property, and decrease user accessibility.
marine coastal flooding.notes: Remember, sea level rise will most likely impact your building through it's role in increasing the severity and frequency of storm and tide-driven extreme coastal flooding events.

An Inventory of Methods for Estimating C.description: provides a comprehensive overview of methods to integrate climate change into flood planning.

PAVICS cloud-based hydrologic model.source: Power Analytics and Visualization for Climate Science
PAVICS cloud-based hydrologic model.description: provides an advanced tool for estimating changes to streamflow due to climate change.

Maximum annual 1-day rain.description: describes maximum annual daily rainfall, which can be important for flooding of smaller creeks and watersheds.

Change in 1-in-50 year snow load.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in 1-in-50 year snow load.description: describes changes in extreme snow loads, based on levels of global warming.

river and lake spring flooding.direction_statement: Climate change will cause changes to river and lake flooding severity and frequency that will depend very closely on location, season, and local watershed factors.
river and lake spring flooding.direction_confidence: It is difficult to make confident statements regarding the direction of climate-driven changes to river and lake flooding severity, without added local information about flood mechanisms and local watershed conditions.
river and lake spring flooding.magnitude_confidence: Because of local factors, estimating the magnitude of changes to river and lake flooding due to climate change is difficult without undertaking a detailed local assessment.
river and lake spring flooding.impact_statement: River/lake flooding has the potential to inundate nearby building interiors, erode foundations and surrounding property, and decrease user accessibility and even safety.
river and lake spring flooding.notes: Add in CanFlood and PAVICS Raven resources

Change in 1-in-50 year annual 15 minute.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in 1-in-50 year annual 15 minute.description: describes changes to the likelihood of rare short term and daily rain events.

extreme rain flooding.direction_statement: Climate change is expected to cause extreme rain events to become more frequent and severe.
extreme rain flooding.direction_confidence: There is high confidence that as temperatures increase, the magnitude of extreme rainfall will also increase.
extreme rain flooding.magnitude_confidence: The exact magnitude of extreme rainfall increases may be somewhat uncertain, especially for high intensity, short duration rainfall events.
extreme rain flooding.impact_statement: Extreme rain can directly damage building components through leaks and infiltration, and also inundate building interiors, erode foundations and surrounding property, and decrease user accessibility from rain-caused overland or flooding.

Change in 1-in-50 year annual 15 minute.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in 1-in-50 year annual 15 minute.description: describes changes to the likelihood of rare short term and daily rain events.

ice jam flooding.direction_statement: Climate change is expected to cause extreme rain events to become more frequent and severe.
ice jam flooding.direction_confidence: There is high confidence that as temperatures increase, the magnitude of extreme rainfall will also increase.
ice jam flooding.magnitude_confidence: The exact magnitude of extreme rainfall increases may be somewhat uncertain, especially for high intensity, short duration rainfall events.
ice jam flooding.impact_statement: Extreme rain can directly damage building components through leaks and infiltration, and also inundate building interiors, erode foundations and surrounding property, and decrease user accessibility from rain-caused overland or flooding.

Change in 1-in-50 year snow load.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in 1-in-50 year snow load.description: describes changes in extreme snow loads, based on levels of global warming.

extreme snow.direction_statement: Extreme snow accumulations over the winter season are likely to decrease in most areas of Canada, with the exception of the North.
extreme snow.direction_confidence: High confidence exists that in many locations, overall snowpack - including extremely high seasonal snowpacks - will decrease as temperatures warm and more precipitation falls as rain.
extreme snow.magnitude_confidence: Because change in snow accumulation depends closely on a combination of temperature and precipitation, the exact magnitude of changes to accumulation over time, and in some places, even uncertainty around the direction of change.
extreme snow.impact_statement: Extreme snow can stress roofs and decrease user accessibility.
extreme snow.notes: Need an assessment of changes to individual snow extreme event frequency/magnitude.

Cooling degree days.description: describes the days that require building cooling.

Change in July 2.5% wet and dry design t.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in July 2.5% wet and dry design t.description: describes changes in building-relevant changes to mid-summer extreme warm temperatures.

extreme heat.direction_statement: Climate change is expected to cause hot summer conditions to increase in frequency and intensity.
extreme heat.direction_confidence: High confidence exists in the projected trend towards warmer summer conditions, as part of overall climate warming.
extreme heat.magnitude_confidence: Since temperature is typically reasonably well captured by climate models, the magnitude of temperatures changes in future projections is reasonably well constrained, for particular future emission scenarios.
extreme heat.impact_statement: Extreme heat can stress building air conditioning systems and cause damage by thermal expansion.

Heating degree days.description: describes the days that require building heating.

Change in January 1% and 2.5% design tem.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in January 1% and 2.5% design tem.description: describes changes in building-relevant changes to mid-winter extreme cold temperatures.

extreme cold.direction_statement: Climate change is expected to cause cold summer days to decrease in frequency and intensity.
extreme cold.direction_confidence: High confidence exists in the projected trend towards less cold winter conditions, as part of overall climate warming.
extreme cold.magnitude_confidence: Since temperature is typically reasonably well captured by climate models, the magnitude of temperatures changes in future projections is reasonably well constrained, for particular future emission scenarios.
extreme cold.impact_statement: Extreme cold can stress building heating systems and potentially cause damage via thermal contraction.

Change in permafrost extent.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in permafrost extent.description: describes changes to Canada's national permafrost extent in terms of percentages and large-scale spatial maps.

Infrastructure in permafrost: a guidelin.description: provides guidance for adapting northern infrastructure including buildings to permafrost loss resulting from climate change.

permafrost loss.direction_statement: Permafrost extent and thickness is expected to decrease substantially with climate warming, at the same time that summer active layer depths increase.
permafrost loss.direction_confidence: High confidence exists projections of permafrost loss in response to warming.
permafrost loss.magnitude_confidence: Since local permafrost conditions are closely controlled by local-scale soil, water, and building factors, the precise magnitude of permafrost loss at a particular location may be uncertain, and require a more detailed assessment to constrain.
permafrost loss.impact_statement: Permafrost loss can cause building subsidence, weaken foundations, promote moisture infiltration, and decrease user accessibility.

Change in 1-in-10 and 1-in-50 year wind.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in 1-in-10 and 1-in-50 year wind.description: describes changes to building-relevant extreme high wind pressures, resulting from high wind speeds.

Change in 1-in-5 year driving rain wind.source: The Climate Resilient Buildings and Core Public Infrastructure Project
Change in 1-in-5 year driving rain wind.description: describes changes to building-relevant extreme high wind pressures, resulting from high wind speeds combined with rain.

high winds.direction_statement: The severity and frequency of high wind speeds and related pressures are currently not projected to change dramatically, although significant uncertainty exists in these projections.
high winds.direction_confidence: There is relatively low confidence in the direction of changes of extreme wind speed severity and frequency, particularly at local scales.
high winds.magnitude_confidence: Low confidence exists for future projections of changes to high winds.
high winds.impact_statement: High winds can damage building envelopes and exterior structures and influence building influence heating and cooling systems.

Fire weather index (FWI).description: describes changes to the upper percentiles of FWI, an index used to determine the potential for wildfire in forests and grasslands.

Average maximum summer temperature.description: describes changes daily maximum summer temperatures

wildfire.direction_statement: Wildfires are expected to worsen in intensity and severity with climate change.
wildfire.direction_confidence: High confidence exists for projections of worsening wildfire intensity and severity.
wildfire.magnitude_confidence: The precise magnitude of future wildfire increases may be uncertain at local scales due to details of wildfire fuel loads and local-scale combined projections of temperature, precipitation, wind and humidity.
wildfire.impact_statement: Wildfire can damage and destroy buildings directly, and also degrade interior air quality through smoke.
